docker-compose.Rmd

Running MIRA with docker-compose

The MIRA’s dashboard relies on four Docker containers to run its genome assembly and curation: IRMA, DAIS-Ribosome, spyne, and MIRA. Presently, the IRMA and DAIS-Ribosome docker images are stored in AWS’s EC, and the spyne and MIRA docker images are stored in Quay.io’s repository. These images can be pulled down and built into runnable containers with the docker pull and docker run commands.

Instead of pulling down each image one by one and run its container, we can utilize docker-compose to pull all the images down at once, build its containers, and configure them to communicate to each other. All these tasks can be accomplished using a docker-compose.yml file.

There are two versions of the docker-compose.yml files:

  • Development version for continuous integration of the application
  • Production version for deployment of the application

Software requirements

  • Docker version >= 20.10,
  • Git version >= 2.21
  • Docker-compose version >= 1.29

Build development version of MIRA

This version allows you to mount the code base that is needed to develop the MIRA dashboard and spyne pipeline. Any updates or changes to the code will automatically reflects the changes inside their Docker containers. This allows continuous integration (CI) of the application.

(1) Clone spyne respitory 

git clone https://git.biotech.cdc.gov/nbx0/spyne.git

(2) Clone MIRA respitory 

git clone https://git.biotech.cdc.gov/nbx0/MIRA.git

(3) Clone mira-testdata respitory 

git clone https://git.biotech.cdc.gov/nbx0/mira-testdata.git

(4) Extract test data for running MIRA and spyne

  • CD to mira-testdata folder where data.tar.gz file is stored and extract “runs” from the tar archive.
[ $( which pigz) ] &&\
    time tar --use-compress-program="pigz -p$(nproc)" -xf data.tar.gz ||\
    tar -xf data.tar.gz

(5) CD to MIRA folder where docker-compose-quay-dev.yml is stored and edit the yaml file to link the data inputs and code base to appropriate containers

  • Mount data directory to /data directory inside of all containers: change /path/to/data to your mira-testdata directory
  • Mount code base of spyne to /spyne directory inside the spyne container: change /path/to/spyne to your spyne directory
  • Mount code base of MIRA to /MIRA directory inside the mira container: change /path/to/MIRA to your MIRA directory
version: "3.9"

x-dais-version:
  &dais-version 
  public.ecr.aws/n3z8t4o2/dais-ribosome:1.2.1

x-irma-version:
  &irma-version 
  public.ecr.aws/n3z8t4o2/irma:1.0.2p3

x-spyne-version:
  &spyne-version 
  quay.io/nbx0_cdc/spyne:v1.1.0

x-mira-version:
  &mira-version 
  quay.io/nbx0_cdc/mira:v1.1.0

x-data-volumes:
  &data-volume
  type: bind
  source: /path/to/data
  target: /data

x-docker-volumes:
  &docker-socket
  type: bind
  source: /var/run/docker.sock 
  target: /var/run/docker.sock 

x-spyne-volumes:
  &spyne-code
  type: bind
  source: /path/to/spyne
  target: /spyne 

x-mira-volumes:
  &mira-code
  type: bind
  source: /path/to/MIRA
  target: /MIRA

(6) Start all services listed in the docker-compose.yml file 

docker-compose up -d

-d: run the containers in detached mode

For more information about the docker-compose syntax, see docker-compose up reference

(7) To check if the services are started sucessfully 

docker-compose ps

(8) Access the MIRA dashboard on the host network

You can visit the local host using your preferred web browser, type in http://localhost:8010, and check if the dashboard is indeed hosted there.

Build production version of MIRA

This version ONLY allows you to mount the data files that are needed to run IRMA, DAIS-Ribosome, spyne, and MIRA containers. In other words, you do not have access to their code base but is using their latest containerized version of the code.

(1) Clone mira-testdata respitory 

git clone https://git.biotech.cdc.gov/nbx0/mira-testdata.git

(2) Extract test data for running MIRA

  • CD to mira-testdata folder where data.tar.gz file is stored and extract “runs” from the tar archive.
[ $( which pigz) ] &&\
    time tar --use-compress-program="pigz -p$(nproc)" -xf data.tar.gz ||\
    tar -xf data.tar.gz

(3) CD to MIRA folder where docker-compose-quay.yml is stored and edit the yaml file to link the data inputs to appropriate containers

  • Mount data directory to /data directory inside of all containers: change /path/to/data to your mira-testdata directory
version: "3.9"

x-dais-version:
  &dais-version 
  public.ecr.aws/n3z8t4o2/dais-ribosome:1.2.1

x-irma-version:
  &irma-version 
  public.ecr.aws/n3z8t4o2/irma:1.0.2p3

x-spyne-version:
  &spyne-version 
  quay.io/nbx0_cdc/spyne:v1.1.0

x-mira-version:
  &mira-version 
  quay.io/nbx0_cdc/mira:v1.1.0

x-data-volumes:
  &data-volume
  type: bind
  source: /path/to/data
  target: /data

x-docker-volumes:
  &docker-socket
  type: bind
  source: /var/run/docker.sock 
  target: /var/run/docker.sock

(4) Start all services listed in the docker-compose.yml file 

docker-compose up -d

-d: run the containers in detached mode

For more information about the docker-compose syntax, see docker-compose up reference

(5) To check if the services are started sucessfully 

docker-compose ps

(6) Access the MIRA dashboard on the host network

You can visit the local host using your preferred web browser, type in http://localhost:8020, and check if the dashboard is indeed hosted there.

NOTE: Here we are publishing the MIRA dashboard on port 8020 on the host machine. This port is different from the development version which was previously launched on port 8010.

Run genome assembly with MIRA

See NGS Training: Running Genome Assembly with MIRA

Getting help

See FAQs Guide on how to upgrade and remove older versions of MIRA using docker-compose
